Last night in class, we discussed that week’s assigned reading, "Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World," by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter addresses “implacement” and the second, “displacement.” In the first chapter, Casey distinguishes that our contemporary world and culture revolve around time as the situating force: we are running out of time, we have saved time, we are just in time. He argues that using place as the center of culture creates a more grounded community. (That is a very rough summation, a disclaimer just in case my professor or any other classmate happens to read this post.) So far, this book is the first reading that has grabbed me by the proverbial shoulders.

GOP gets scolded on recruitment; naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville are to be relocated after complaints that GOP activists registered new citizens as Republicans. By Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy. The citizenship ceremony in Jacksonville seemed to proceed as usual, with a crowd of nearly 200 people leaving as new Americans. Just before the new citizens departed the June 29 event, an immigration official directing the swearing-in urged them to stop by a voter registration table—a common sight at naturalization ceremonies. But this table was unusual: those distributing forms were Republican volunteers—and the party affiliation box had already been checked to make all the new voters members of the GOP. All of it was suspicious to Linda Cross, who was there to witness her husband, Dario Cruz, take his citizenship oath.

I entered volume and pricing for the following two deals in Sitara: Deal 418015 for CNG citygate with Tenn Prod plus transport pricing and Deal 418065 for CGAS citygate with TRCO and CGLF production and transport pricing (this will take time). The simplest approach I've devised is to enter the sales at the citygate or storage facility and complete most of the pricing in a worksheet.

It puts the ball in the net or it gets the hose again. Absolutely amazing, I have nothing negative to say about this game as it's exceeded my expectations and will probably exceed yours too. Fluid movement, bug/crash free, with lots of story/content to immerse you, options for each and every day such as multiple practices, events (sponsorships), and even games. This review is purely based on playing MyCareer, and so far it's 10/10. Face scan worked really well for me (used it twice, the first one gave me a strange forehead though..). Keep in mind, using the MyNBA2K17 app will allow you to face scan for free and earn daily VC. #sellout

Magic fans beware... Wizards is hesitant to create a decent digital game. At its core, Magic: The Gathering is a social game—a game to enjoy with your friends (or frenemies), laughing, bantering, and unleashing game-winning moves. Wizards of the Coast seems to have overlooked this. If you choose to play with friends, you can't earn gold, which is crucial. Gold is so crucial that they have implemented a daily cap, understandable since gold unlocks everything in the game. But prepare for a long and monotonous 1v1 grind against the computer or random opponents, whom you can't even speak to. If you choose to play for free, it will take you roughly 4 hours a day for about a month, by yourself, to unlock the cards.

Being the third installment in the trilogy, I'll address the negative aspects first. I quite dislike prequels, as they technically move backwards in a story rather than forwards (this is an issue with every prequel). Granted, they offer more in terms of story. The combat feels sloppy and lacks the sharpness that Arkham City managed to achieve. As of writing this recommendation (26/10/2013), there is a game-breaking bug that prevents a side mission from ever being completed (main story not affected). Some gadgets are assigned to a ridiculous hotkey, forcing your hand to travel across the entire keyboard. It might sound trivial, but in combat it could potentially disrupt your combo.

They expertly refined Shadow Warrior (2013). The boss fights are fantastic, and weapons feel very satisfying (perhaps not as impressive as Doom's, but still solid). Enemies aren't too resilient (if you wisely handle elemental and upgrade elements). The upgrade system is well-balanced, and once you understand it, it's not too tedious. The elemental features and limited ammo gently encourage you to use various weapons. There are many cool, unique (an important point when comparing SW2 to Borderlands' formula of 'random' weapons) weapons that remain effective through most of the game. The music is excellent, especially the main theme and, of course, Stan Bush's contributions.

So many things were done wrong. I don't even know how to start this review. This all refers to my career. My player is an outside scorer, pg, 1.71m, has maxed stats and already obtained all necessary perks. OK, and now tell me, why does shooting skill depend on a person's height? Why can a person who is 1.74m not become as good at shooting as a person with 1.71m? I'm 1.87m in real life, created my first player with this height, and noticed I cannot reach a skill above 89. Why? That's pure discrimination! And why doesn't the game tell me that before I create a character and not even when I reach the skill limit after weeks of playing?!

I think this Assassin's Creed nailed the mechanics on all fronts (ship battles, sailing, hunting, parkour, etc). I felt much more attached to the character as well. The story starts out quite rough but does get significantly better as you play (I think this is true for every AC game, personally). Edward was quite the interesting character, as were all the side characters. I felt like all the collectibles actually meant something in this AC game, unlike any of the previous ones. Maybe it's because they had a bigger purpose in the game. They definitely were not required, but they were fun to collect, and you got rewarded in a very balanced way.

While I personally cannot recommend this game, it wasn't absolutely terrible. The gunplay is decent, provided you have the money to purchase gun parts, which is my main complaint: it's pay-to-win. If I could overlook that, the game would be enjoyable, as the hardsuit is fun to use, and HRV is an excellent idea. I'd choose this game over any Call of Duty title any day, but its pay-to-win microtransaction format is off-putting for me. If you are comfortable with this model, by all means, have fun. But if you're like me and dislike pay-to-win games, just let this one slide; it's not our cup of tea.

While not perfect, this game has been highly enjoyable. The save system and risk of sudden death can lead to some frustration. I'm on my first playthrough and lost my main character around hour 10 of 20ish. I would have really appreciated a save to reload at that point. I've since picked up a third-party mod/save tool to avoid catastrophic failures. Additionally, the aiming reticule is somewhat small and the zoom is underpowered. With all that said, it's been a blast. I'm not usually a fan of zombie games, but the combination of strategy, missions, first-person shooter/beat ‘em up elements is great. I've been playing it as often as possible... Just one more mission, just one more supply run—or I’m running away and want to get safe before shutting the game down.

An absolutely great strategy game! Having played every single other wargame (European Escalation and ALB), I have to say this one fits well. The number of units is great. Not sure exactly how many units there are, but there's a ton! Graphics are beautiful, sounds are great, and the gameplay overall is epic. The in-game chat box at the main menu is very entertaining as well, no I am not kidding. However, if anyone thinks this game is 'easy', or if you are new to the strategy genre, it could take you quite some time to get it nailed down. Do not get upset, you will lose a lot of units. Just make sure you plan ahead, always have anti-air and anti-tank.

I was negatively biased towards this game before I played it. Wasn't even sure about buying it. I didn't know—the whole portal gun and portals thing seemed weird to me even though I like science fiction. Boy, was I wrong. The jokes and voice acting in this game are phenomenal. Just amazing. It's not cheesy (okay, it's sometimes cheesy). And different story characters each have their own sense of humor. Those different characters really have distinct personalities. And the level design; it's just rad. By the way, I never played the first Portal game. One of these days, I'm planning to if I can spare the time. I would never have played it if I hadn't played the sequel.

Okay, let's start with the pros (+) and cons (-), then my thoughts on this game. +Some of the best characters +Good story +Loads of content +Customizable character (you can be male or female, whichever you like) +You can have a relationship with most of your companions (yes, fangirls, you can have a love interest) -Bad graphics (I don't think graphics really matter anyway) -Weird and awkward love scenes -Invisible walls -There's one mission, in my opinion, that was boring, but everyone has different tastes -+ This isn't really bad or good, but your protagonist can't talk for those who care. Okay, now for my thoughts. I love this game. This game is probably one of the best RPGs or games, in general, I have ever played. If you're an RPG fan, you probably already have this game.

Certainly, here's the polished version with exactly 12 words edited:

Yes, this is a nostalgia trip for thirty-somethings who remember (at least in the UK) watching the ever-irritating Timmy Mallet just for the five-minute Transformers cartoon. The voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and many others are back and instantly recognizable. The distinctive cartoon transformation sound is there. Graphically, the cel-shaded presentation is perfect, and very, very Generation One. But beyond that, it's actually a very enjoyable game. The combat mechanics are extremely well done. Transforming mid-fight is often a necessity and seamlessly woven into combos, making it quite unlike High Moon's excellent War for/Fall of Cybertron games. Another distinction is the strong focus on melee combat, but some enemies (e.g., Seekers) require switching to a ranged blaster.

I downloaded the game and played it for a little while, and it was nothing special. I spent more time trying to log in than actually playing. There's a bug where it says there's an update to the terms of service, and whenever you click 'accept,' it just pops up again. You have to restart the client for it to work. That isn't so bad, but why do I need to link my Steam and Gface accounts? They say it's for DLC, but why is that necessary? It's also not reversible, so now I know that a company I don't care about has access to my Steam information. The game itself is mediocre. It's easily recognizable as a COD clone, except somehow they made the gunplay worse... How is that even possible?

4k+ at 60fps (GTX 970), dual audio options, and includes Neptune gear. What's not to love? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo Excellent port and a great entry point if new to the series. Just keep in mind there is lots of (skippable) dialogue. As usual, I would suggest using a gamepad, but personally, I had no problems with a keyboard/mouse setup, both completely rebindable. Price is about right and I wouldn't have been unhappy with the purchase. More than half the DLC is included free, which is still plenty to play with. Recommended game to all JRPG/anime/visual novel fans, provided you don't mind long breaks between the action. Cheers. No commentary playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=plslfvijaupszez9af395mvnk63xnhsj1_

I experienced no performance issues even at release, and after all these patches, it plays excellently. In my opinion, this is a truly great and fun game, although the format may be somewhat annoying (where the free-roam city area repopulates with new enemies every time you progress the story). I particularly enjoyed the 'dual play' segments (where you can play Batman and one more character), and the ability to use the controller for most parts of the game, while the mouse and keyboard for the tank combat segments was greatly appreciated. Driving your Batmobile around the free-roam city, including while chasing the APC commanders, is actually quite enjoyable once you figure out how to use the brakes to skid around corners (and when you master that, navigating the city is really quite enjoyable!).

Outstanding first-person shooter—that's the takeaway. It looks, sounds, and plays excellently, with great FPS mechanics, an engaging story, captivating characters, flawless voice acting, and an amazing soundtrack. Not for the fainthearted, though; some of those cutscenes were quite intense and vivid. However, when a game is this good, the flaws become more noticeable, and here they are as I saw them: no SLI support—unbelievable! I had to set the game aside until I upgraded my card, as it ran too poorly on my old dual-GPU GTX 590. Ensure you have a decent single GPU card. Also, annoyingly small obstacles are often unclimbable.

English is not my native language. I am Dutch. So please overlook any typing/grammatical mistakes in my review of this fantastic game. I will break down this review into a few categories: - graphics - controls - sound - gameplay - replayability - graphics: the game is set in a comic-like style. The graphics are very sleek: no unnecessary details. Nice color schemes. It totally works for this game. The graphics can be set on 'high' without stressing your system. I run this game on an i5 Pentium processor, with Nvidia GeForce 710M card - 8GB memory and it runs like clockwork (Windows 8.1). - controls: the game can be played with keyboard and mouse, but also with an Xbox controller.

You can see from the hours I put into this game that I enjoy it. This is everything I wished a search game from COD would be. But don’t buy this game thinking it's like COD, Battlefield, or any other shooter game. It's a game in its own class and should be treated as such. I can’t tell you how many times I hear new players complain about getting killed really fast. Oh, forbid you get shot in the face and die. It's not like that doesn’t happen in real life or anything. Edit: I’ve been playing this game for a while now and thrown all kinds of money at it. One of the best MP games around. A good thing to play when you're not feeling CS:GO.

I'm 2 hours in and am dying from this game. It's so funny. Gameplay is solid, the art design is beautiful, music is surprisingly high quality and fitting, the story/world has me intrigued, and the puzzles are fun. But the best thing about this game beyond all that is the comedy. If you've played any RPG since the dawn of video game RPGs, you will laugh at the various jokes, parodies, and references; if you've never played an RPG before, you'll still enjoy the game for its humor. If you played Final Fantasy VII or X, you absolutely need to play this game. Without giving too much away, I had to actually stop playing after 2 hours to give my cheeks a break from laughing and smiling so much. What a delight so far!

I'm truly sorry, I try to be supportive of free-to-play games and indie developers, but I really didn't enjoy this game. The description sounded perfect for me, but the execution has done nothing for me. I love puzzle and exploration games, but I found this game completely unintuitive, and even after looking up how to progress, I still simply didn't find the gameplay itself fun. It also completely lacks a pause button, or if it does have one, I never found it. Considering that many sequences in the game are timed, this seems like a critical oversight. I also feel like this game is more cut scene than an actual game, and I end up just sitting around drumming my fingers a lot.

This game... Phew, where to even start. It was absolutely beautiful; from the story to the graphics, I was hooked. The story wasn't just any story but actually felt like I was that person, trying to figure out what came next in the tale my character was narrating. The gameplay was great, and I learned a lot about myself through this game (mainly my fear of heights, which I never had an issue with until the ice caverns). My gut churned the whole time, but I persevered for Uncle Fred! If you guys made a DLC or second game, I would be the first to buy it and recommend it to everyone I know. Thanks to everyone who was involved in making this; you created an absolutely beautiful game.

Sid Meier's Civilization Beyond Earth is a turn-based game where you build your civilization toward a specific goal or "victory." In previous games, you were set on Earth's timeline, going through periods like the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and Modern Age; however, in this game, you are set in the future on a mission to colonize a new planet. What I enjoy about this game is that 2K took a new approach and added some exciting mechanics such as the affinity system and orbital layer. What I didn't enjoy was that these new mechanics could make the game overwhelming at times. What I think could be improved is incorporating new artwork into the game, such as the environment you experience when communicating with another leader.

Great game! Tons of replayability and a very fun zombie survival game! Definitely in my top 5 zombie games ever played. Edit: After playing 60+ hours, I can honestly say this is one of the better, more "realistic" zombie games. It’s very much designed like a survival horror as you must conserve your ammo, heal your wounds when you bleed out, take pills when you're infected, etc. Also, I find the zombies to be well-animated and quite natural for a free-to-play game. P.S.: I would recommend getting 1 or 2 friends to play with, but the community is super friendly, and you can usually make friends or chat with people in the chat or over voice comms.

02/07/2014 - It's unfortunate I can't fully recommend or enjoy this game. From the short time I've played, I know I'd be hooked if it weren't for the following two game breakers. No Aussie servers: one red bar puts you at a severe disadvantage and creates unbearable lag. Even offline training mode was stuttering and lagging (how does that even happen?). Combine that with the poor ping, and it just ruins the experience. Everything artifacts like crazy—the menus, backgrounds, training, and in-game. I've never had this happen before with this card and thought it might not like my OC. Set my GPU back to stock and, sure enough, it didn't make a difference.

Very late last night, I finished this. The story isn't very deep or interesting, but what makes it stand out is the storytelling. The atmosphere is full to the brim, and the many collectibles do a great job of fleshing it out. I learned a lot about the world of Batman, so it was a bit disappointing that so few bosses were in the game. Oh well, there are enough future games to rectify that. The combat is the right amount of challenge, but it's more on the easy side. Leveling up Batman wasn't very satisfying. It's the gadgets you upgrade and acquire during the campaign that add nice new gameplay mechanics. Gaining access to previously unreachable places offers a nice sense of progression.

'To the Moon' is no mere game... Nay, it is a veritable experience, and one of the best of my life at that. Think Telltale's 'The Walking Dead' is sad? Hohoho! Well, it's no match for 'To the Moon'! Never before have I been so depressed yet fulfilled by something purely fictional. This masterpiece represents the pinnacle of storytelling, in my opinion, and the soundtrack is a gorgeously charming and perfect accompaniment. Yes, the controls are a bit finicky and the gameplay is not the strong point, but the story is so fantastic that I did not care one bit. Plus, the humor of the game is great as well and it does not intrude upon the distinguished nature of the story... And the 'Doctor Who' references are endless.

Bastion is a brilliantly crafted game with a compelling storyline. Set in the aftermath of a calamity, you start rebuilding on the bastion. There’s a significant amount of choice in the game, including what to build to gain an advantage, which weapons to use, and which power-ups to enhance those weapons, as well as which drinks to use for a bonus effect. The art style and music in the game are fantastic, and everything looks vibrant; who says the apocalypse has to be dull? Best of all, the game features narration based on your actions. So if you pick up a weapon and then switch it for another in the armory, the narration reflects your choice, commenting on your selection of the new weapon.

I originally bought this game during its early development, when the only currency was spacebux, and there was no 'tech tree'. This was when the game was great. All the guns were equally overpowered, so there were no issues with imbalance; everyone could eliminate anyone at any time. Additionally, the game used to offer unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. You would think that for a game boasting 'bajillions of guns', they would at least provide more than 6 weapon slots and 3 loadouts before you have to pay for additional ones. At one point, I had about 3 pages of guns and was planning new ideas for more because, personally, that's where I found the fun.

This game was a surprising gem. One often sees rave reviews of certain products that are often misleading. In this case, the reviews reflect the fun of this neat little game. It is an intriguing mix between a classic 2D platformer and a MOBA, and does it with style. I found myself enjoying characters that I wouldn't enjoy in other MOBA games. I had expected this trend to continue, but decided to give a melee tank a try anyway. I was pleasantly surprised with the outcome and ended up trying out more as they were unlocked from playing games. The art style and interface are surprisingly charming. As such, I now use one of the characters as my avatar and a wallpaper from creating a card set for the game.

I just started playing, but I love this game. I put on my headphones and lose myself in the game for hours at a time. It's been a while since a game had that effect on me. The music sets the mood, the sound effects are spot on, and the controls are perfect. I look forward to every battle, and they've optimized combat extremely well. I had my doubts about the naval combat system, but it's so much fun to lay waste to multiple fleets! The only way to lose in this game is to fail to retreat. If the combat looks overwhelming, just get out of there, regroup, and counter-assault. Thanks, devs, for an awesome experience!

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has brought about many changes for the series, particularly for the series’ protagonist, Dante. While fans of the original series may be upset by the change to their beloved character, it’s certainly for the better; and this new game by Ninja Theory proves it. DMC serves as the perfect point for newcomers to jump into the series. It shows the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante and chronicles his journey from cynicism to selflessness. Throughout, the game weaves a clear narrative arc for the new Dante, making him a compelling character to watch. The story follows Dante as he’s introduced to the corrupt world he willfully chose to ignore.

Where do I start with this absolutely beautiful game? Its story is absolutely charming. It has so much detail put into it and is a bundle of happiness, bad puns, annoying dogs, and secrets. It is serious when it needs to be but isn't a stranger to funny moments. The character design is on point, with various characters possessing different personalities and secrets. It stands out from other RPGs because you don't have to kill anyone, which is an uncommon concept in RPGs. With lots of inspiration from EarthBound, one of the best RPGs I've seen, you can tell that it is going to be good. It easily has the best soundtrack I've heard in ages.

I am recommending this solely because it's free and might be a more 'enjoyable' experience for others. As for my experience, the 'game' did nothing for me. Half the story relies on shock factor. I was neither shocked nor emotionally moved in any way. Maybe I'm desensitized, or maybe it was too simple to warrant a reaction from me. As for the other half of the game, it tries to paint a picture (literally) of a person in mental decline. It deals with obsession, hallucination, depression, and a few other things. In theory, it is a cool idea. But the 'game' took me 10 minutes to complete, and that is with reading and absorbing every little bit of information I could.

Do I even need to explain why Portal is amazing? Portal is a puzzle game; it gives you a concept, then steps aside. It is an excellent way to challenge your mind while staying entertaining. Although this game isn't as story-heavy, it led to the creation of one of the most popular games of 2011. I still play this game and complete it when I feel bored, and I love returning to see what birthed a legend. Gameplay: Portal's gameplay is quite simple, at least to explain. You use portals to your advantage, along with buttons that activate a part of the puzzle. Two types of buttons are in the game: one that you press and one that requires a cube to activate.

If you can overlook the bugs (I personally experienced only two: one minor and the other quite annoying) edit: both bugs are resolved. One fix increased my fps from 60-90 to 80-120. If you are looking for a space exploration game, I can definitely recommend this. Since most of these reviews are about specs, I'll include mine: i5 6600k (~200€) Radeon RX480 (~200€) Z170 Pro - Gaming (~150€) 16GB DDR4 RAM (~70€) ~650€ is definitely within the medium price range though, granted, this rig is quite new. Almost constant 60+ fps on high settings with VSync enabled. I genuinely can't believe 90% of the comments saying they're using an overkill setup and get 20fps.

Remember Age of Mythology? Yeah, it's been a long time since there's been an RTS game of such quality. Divinity: Dragon Commander reaches very close to these borders of my personal favorite RTS game. Combine this with a substantial risk-like grand strategy mode, and there, it hits the spot. I try not to be overly biased due to the fact that this game allows you to turn into a dragon, aiding your troops by supporting, attacking, and even commanding unit production, direction, and spawning at the same time. Honestly, I do prefer the complex RTS games nowadays. Think of Civ V and so on. However, such games attempt to cram complex mechanics, charts, and resources all into one complicated game mode.

Undertale combines elements to create something greater than the sum of its parts. The graphics are solid for a retro title and the music is nice, but together they create truly beautiful and impactful moments. The script ranges from comedic to dramatic to heartbreaking to hopeful, sometimes all at once, and accomplishes this while subverting RPG tropes. And all of this without mentioning the world, characters, story, or gameplay... I could write entire pages about it. But instead, I'll just say this: if you like RPGs, play this game. If you enjoy video games, play this game. If you have seven free hours between now and your death, play this game.

If you liked Witcher 1 and 2, Witcher 3 is a must-have. I would normally give this game a 10/10, but unfortunately after 1.03, it turned into a buggy mess with random crashes, so remember to save frequently. When I played versions 1.00 to 1.03, my game never crashed, and I didn’t see any bugs. I have noticed that after the 1.03 patch, the drawing distance sometimes is terrible, starting to draw objects only when you're really close, sometimes even people. However, ignoring these bugs, crashes, and draw-distance issues, this is a truly fantastic game. They put a huge effort into the quests, with some being really emotional and deep, lots of side quests, and the fact that your decisions affect a lot in this game. I have played over 50 hours now and am still going.

I have only had this game for a few months, but in just that short amount of time, two DLCs have been released, along with patches that have transformed an already great game into an excellent one. The developers are very active in the community, and it really shows in the various discussion forums and developer diaries. There is a fairly steep learning curve to the game's mechanics, which I am still trying to learn; however, this breadth of strategy allows you numerous ways to reach goals and take advantage of certain situations. The game, in my mind, is almost infinitely replayable. I find myself immersed in every session I play, regardless of how the playthrough is going.

Warframe is a fun game for the first few hours of play. After those few enjoyable hours, you'll begin to see that the only thing the game offers is repetition in its combat, enemies, and gameplay. The one major high point is that the developers work hard and do semi-frequent updates, generally including much content, from sweeping changes to some of the game's systems, new warframes, and other tweaks/features. It's a good game to play casually, though I doubt it will hold your attention beyond a few months unless you really enjoy grinding. The upside to all of this is that the game is free, so I'd recommend trying it out. If you're looking for a quick fix, try it out.

This game is so... incredibly boring. I bought this game because I believed it was a PC version of 'Katamari Damacy', a popular and delightful PS2 game. Sadly, it’s far from it. In this game, you go about absorbing increasingly larger objects to grow bigger and absorb even larger items. Yet, the gameplay isn’t as smooth as it could be, the levels lack inventiveness, and what’s present is a surreal horror show. I don’t mean an entertaining horror show but one that leaves you rather depressed and questioning if being alive is all it should be. Every 'living' creature in this game, from small pets to human beings, makes me wonder if the creators had an interest in taxidermy.

Alright, let me explain a few things. As a person deeply interested in politics, I was very excited about this game when I first heard about it. I thought, "Oh wow! A simulator of the road to becoming president! That sounds fun!" Well, it really wasn't. The game starts you off by asking you to pick a side: Republican or Democrat—there is no independent or third party option. A little disappointed but still optimistic, I carried on to see what I could do. I will give the game credit: the character customization, although limited, is pretty fun to explore. It's the only time it's an option to wear your head or not in a campaign. Literally.

The story of Fallout 3 was better. Settlements interfere with the narrative to the point where you'll resent managing them instead of progressing in the story. Some keys are hard-coded and cannot be reconfigured. Numerous bugs exist. My Pip-Boy disappeared permanently at one point, requiring me to research console commands to restore it. You don't have to work for power armor; it's essentially given to you at the beginning of the game, and power cores are readily available in trader shops. The value of power armor is greatly diminished compared to previous Fallout games. The story is mediocre, and everything about this game is unremarkable, except it doesn't crash every 10 minutes like Fallout 3. It is much more stable compared to Fallout 3. Is it better than Fallout 3? No. Is it better than New Vegas? No. This title was so overhyped for how poor it actually is.

My stats (at the time of writing this review): - 8.6 hrs to complete - 10 collectibles found out of 25 - zero achievements out of 15 what I liked: - visuals until the last level (ice caves) - story is not that great, but the ending (after the closing credits) somewhat made me not regret spending my time on this game what I disliked: - visuals in the last level are uninteresting - gameplay in the last level becomes much harder, making it a frustrating experience of having to repeat actions until you succeed - achievements are too hard. There are 13 (out of 15) that fewer than 2.1% of players achieved!

Pros: +graphic  
Cons: -bugs (especially in the environment, where you may get stuck or your shots may hit an invisible wall despite having a clear line of sight to the enemy) -handholding gameplay -poor AI -enemies always seem to know your location when you're spotted -godlike enemy accuracy, just like the first Ghost Warrior -terrible checkpoints and saves -boring story that I couldn't care less about. I will not recommend it unless it's 90% off; even then, I find playing this game an extremely boring chore, played only to finish it and move on to the next game in my library. Considering the time wasted on the first Ghost Warrior (which was equally boring and I felt liberated when I finished it), I probably won't play it to the end.

Review for 29/11/2015: Do not buy this game; servers are offline. You can't play. No compres este juego, servidores offline. No puedes jugar. When I was able to play it, I enjoyed it. As the song by The Steve Miller Band goes: Go on, take the money and run, uh uh uhhh! Go on, take the money and run! https://youtu.be/-wcfugcollu?t=54 --- English - 73 minutes playing the game. OMG, just an hour in, and it's awesome! Some guns are overpowered, and the matchmaking is sometimes unfair. But hey, BF3 was worse; the matchmaking put newbies against higher-level players who weren't real humans. You shot them in the face, and nothing happened!

Who wouldn't want to wear a fez? This puzzle platforming game stars a little character with a fez who collects bits to form a cube and navigates a fairly large branching map. This game is amusing, and completing it was quite fun. However, it can become semi-frustrating if you aim to collect all the cubes and achievements. To obtain all cubes, you'll need to crack codes that require deciphering. These can take a few seconds or frustrate you into using a guide (*raises hand* I gave up). The guide, 'A Complete Guide to Fez.'

It's not difficult for me to understand why other people enjoy this game, but it wasn't for me. For one thing, I have a Vive and I'm much more interested in playing room-scale games with the controllers. Beyond that, the game is initially awe-inspiring in the scale of its universe, but I also felt that same scale was a hindrance to my enjoyment. The learning curve and the amount of time needed to do anything interesting at the beginning were both too large for me. Perhaps if I were more patient and had more time for gaming, this would be compelling to me. But I don't have either, and there are plenty more VR games I'd rather spend my time on.

Undoubtedly, my favorite first-person shooter of all time. Run-and-gun players need not apply. Recoil and ballistics are realistic. Single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle-caliber weapons almost always result in death unless they just graze you. Rounds drop over distance, and short, controlled bursts are required if you wish to remain on target. There is no magical ammunition pool. If you reload halfway through your magazine all the time, then you will have a pouch full of half-full mags. You can't run forever. If you sprint for a while, your aim will suffer as you gasp heavily until you've caught your breath. Rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a window sill to steady your aim. Accuracy suffers when standing.

Let me start by saying I did not purchase EU when it first came out; I got it on sale, which included EW, so I never experienced the issues some people claim to have had. I loved that game; however, it was unforgiving in the early stages but rewarding when you did things right. As for XCOM 2, I love it. The game plays well for me on medium, and I am running a GTX 560 with 2 GB of VRAM. Initially, the game set itself to high, and it ran a bit sluggishly but not to the point of being unplayable. When I dropped it to medium, it smoothed out. I'm not sure if I'm just lucky with games, or what, but it seems most negative reviews sound like they come from some really entitled people.

+RPG leveling +wide variety of ship types +physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missiles +easy-to-learn resource management +dark humor -grind-intensive (if underutilizing the civvy station types) -subpar AI teammates -low variety of equipment types -low variety of leveling skills (that is, no branching) Listen, this game is fun as hell. Despite my minuses up there, there is still some variety and strategy to be had. It starts off fast and really picks up. Even though there's a low variety of equipment, it still feels like there's always another ship to unlock or skill to level up. The best way to enhance the life of this game is the mods. Fight for Universe is easily the star, but Big Fight for Beef is also very good.

World leaders gather to face uncertainty as over 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe arrive in the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). For five days, they will discuss issues ranging from China's economic power to Iraq's future after this Sunday's elections. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among the more than 20 government leaders and heads of state attending the meeting. Unlike previous years, protests against the WEF are expected to be muted. Anti-globalisation campaigners have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend. The Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, timed to run in parallel with the WEF's grander event in Davos.

The deadline approaches for the Fiat-GM deal as Fiat and General Motors (GM) have until midnight on February 1 to resolve a disagreement over a potential takeover. This deadline marks when Fiat is entitled to sell its car division to GM, part of an alliance agreed upon in 2000. GM, whose own European operations are losing money, no longer wants to own the unprofitable Fiat unit. Reports of deadlocked talks sent Fiat shares down 1.2% on Tuesday after Monday's 4% gain on hopes of a resolution. The US firm is believed to be offering about $2 billion (£1.06bn) to extricate itself from the arrangement. It has argued the deal was voided by Fiat's decision to sell off its finance arm and halve GM's stake via a capital-raising effort. The 2000 deal resulted from a race between GM and DaimlerChrysler to ally with Fiat.

Cardinal criticizes Iraq war cost. Billions of pounds spent on conflict in Iraq and the Middle East should have been used to reduce poverty, Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has said. The head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales made the comments on BBC Radio 4 and will reiterate his stance in his Christmas Midnight Mass. The Cardinal used a Christmas message to denounce the war in Iraq as a "terrible" waste of money. He and the Archbishop of Canterbury have both spoken out about the war. Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Thought for the Day slot, he criticized the fact that "billions" have been spent on war, instead of being used to bring people "out of dire poverty, malnourishment, and disease." The Cardinal said 2005 should be the year for campaigning to "make poverty history.

British stars were denied major Oscars as UK hopefuls failed to win acting and directing prizes. Despite three nominations, Mike Leigh's Vera Drake did not secure the director or screenplay awards, and there was no prize for star Imelda Staunton either. Kate Winslet also lost to Best Actress winner Hilary Swank, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo failed to win Best Supporting Actor awards. The UK's Andrea Arnold won the Short Film award for her gritty drama Wasp. Arnold, who presented children's television shows Number 73 and Motormouth in the 1980s, said it was "totally overwhelming" to win. Wasp tells the story of a single mother living on the breadline, surpassing films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Halloween screenwriter Debra Hill dies screenwriter and producer Debra Hill, best known for her work on the 70s horror classic Halloween, has died in Los Angeles at age 54. Hill, who had been suffering from cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film, which starred Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, it made over $60 million (£31.3 million) worldwide - a record for independent film at that time. Hill also worked with Carpenter on Escape from New York and The Fog. Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant and worked her way through the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before she began collaborating with Carpenter. She was regarded by many as a pioneering woman in film, taking on jobs in the 70s that were more commonly held by men.

Broadband fuels online expression; fast web access encourages more people to express themselves online, research suggests. A quarter of broadband users in Britain regularly upload content and have personal websites, according to a report by UK think tank Demos. It noted that having an always-on, fast connection changes how people use the internet. More than five million households in the UK have broadband, and that number is growing rapidly. The Demos report examined the impact of broadband on people's internet habits. It found that more than half of those with broadband logged on to the web before breakfast. One in five even admitted to getting up in the middle of the night to browse online. More significantly, the report argues, broadband is encouraging people to take a more active role online.

Yukos heads back to U.S. courts as the Russian oil and gas company is due in a U.S. court on Thursday, continuing its fight for survival. The firm is undergoing dismantling by Russian authorities to pay a $27bn (£14bn) tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the U.S., hoping to use international business law to stop the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. The unit was, however, sold for $9.4bn to state oil firm Rosneft, but only after the state auction was disrupted. Yukos lawyers argue that the auction violated U.S. bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to pursue any company that buys its assets, using all legal means.

Voters flock to blog awards site as voting is underway for the annual Bloggies, which recognize the best web blogs—online spaces where people publish their thoughts—of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but traffic to the official site was so heavy that the website was temporarily closed due to too many visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a huge year, with a leading US dictionary naming "blog" the word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs and says that more than 12,000 are added daily. A blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to US research think tank Pew Internet and American Life, but less than 40% of the total are updated at least once every two months.

Chinese dam firm 'defies Beijing': The China Three Gorges Project Corp is refusing to comply with a government order to stop construction of one of its giant dams, the Chinese state press has reported. The builder of the Three Gorges Dam is continuing work on the sister Xiluodu Dam, noted the Beijing News. The Xiluodu Dam is among 30 large-scale construction projects halted due to insufficient environmental checks. The Beijing News mentioned the company might instead opt to pay a fine. The firm has also disregarded orders to stop construction at two other projects - the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Project Electrical Power Supply Plant. Thus far, only 22 of the 30 construction projects targeted by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for not carrying out mandatory environmental impact assessments have complied with its shutdown order.

Manchester United reduced Chelsea's Premiership lead to nine points after a scrappy victory over Manchester City, ending with a score of 2-0. Wayne Rooney met Gary Neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which deflected off Richard Dunne, putting United ahead. Just seven minutes later, the unfortunate Dunne hooked a volley over David James' head and into his own net. Steve McManaman squandered City's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes, United had appeared unlikely to secure the win they needed to maintain any hope of catching Chelsea in the title race. Their approach play was more labored than patient, and they managed to create just one chance—a Paul Scholes header over the bar.

Wales 'must learn health lessons,' says the new health minister for Wales, who believes there are lessons to learn from England in addressing waiting lists. Dr. Brian Gibbons, on his first full day in the role after Jane Hutt was dismissed, acknowledged "big challenges" but insisted the "essentials" were in place. However, both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats stated Dr. Gibbons needed to revise policy. Meanwhile, Ms. Hutt defended her record, asserting that waiting times and lists represented "only 10% of the health agenda." Dr. Gibbons, a former GP in Blaengwynfi, in the upper Afan Valley, before becoming AM for Aberavon, said NHS staff desired a period of consolidation after "tremendous change and reform." One of the significant challenges Ms. Hutt faced during her five and a half years as the assembly's first health minister was the lengthy waiting lists in Wales.

Ferguson hails Man Utd's resolve. Manchester United's Alex Ferguson praised his players' gutsy performance in the 1-0 win at Aston Villa. "That was our hardest away game of the season and it was a fantastic game of football, end-to-end with lots of good passing," said the Old Trafford boss. "We showed lots of character and guts and we weren't going to lose. I look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while Arsenal and Chelsea have yet to come, and Villa may have some players back when they do." Ferguson also hailed senior stars Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who came off the bench for the injured John O'Shea. "Roy came on and brought composure to the midfield, which we needed and which no other player has.

Singer's film to show at festival: A documentary taking a candid look at the life of chart-topping singer George Michael will be shown at this year's Berlin Film Festival. "A Different Story" will screen in the Panorama section, which runs from February 10-20. It features Michael discussing both his career and personal life, from his days in Wham! to more recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on February 16. Director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens will also attend. The 93-minute film will see Michael discussing his early days in Wham! as well as his later career, including his legal battles with record label Sony and his stance against the Iraq War and American politics.

Digital music downloads are now being included in the main US singles chart for the first time. Billboard's Hot 100 chart now incorporates data from music download sales, previously only featured on a separate download chart. Green Day's "Boulevard of Broken Dreams" is currently number two on Billboard's pop chart, and tops its digital chart. Download sales are expected to be incorporated into the UK singles chart later this year. Digital sales in the US are already used to compile Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. They will now be tallied with physical singles sales and airplay information to form its new Hot 100 chart. Its second new chart - the Pop 100 - also combines airplay, digital and physical sales but confines its airplay information to US radio stations that play chart music.

Anti-spam laws hit a spammer hard: the internet's self-declared spam king is seeking bankruptcy protection. Scott Richter, the man behind OptinRealBig.com and billions of junk mail messages, said lawsuits have forced the company into Chapter 11. OptinRealBig was fighting several legal battles, most notably against Microsoft, which is seeking millions of dollars in damages. The company stated that filing for Chapter 11 would assist in resolving its legal issues while continuing to operate. Listed as the third biggest spammer in the world by junk mail watchdog Spamhaus, OptinRealBig was sued in December 2003 for sending mail messages that violated anti-spam laws. The lawsuit was brought by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, who alleged that Mr. Richter and his accomplices sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised net addresses in 35 countries.

Arnesen denies rift with Santini Tottenham Sporting Director Frank Arnesen has denied that coach Jacques Santini resigned due to a clash of personalities at White Hart Lane. There had been newspaper speculation that Santini felt undermined by Arnesen's role at the club. "It is absolutely not true," Arnesen told BBC Radio Five Live. "There is only one thing that made him resign, and that is his own personal problems. He has talked to me recently and said this matter is absolutely for himself." Arnesen said he was unable to shed any light on the problems that caused Santini to quit after just 13 games in charge. He added: "Jacques has never gone into exactly what it was. But I trust him in that; you have to accept it. I think we should respect it.

Ireland surged past Scotland as they maintained their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions with an impressive victory at Murrayfield. Hugo Southwell's try gave the Scots an early 8-0 lead, but scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put the visitors in command by half-time. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and a third penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed victory. After two hard-earned away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's side can now look forward to welcoming England to Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Scotland will try to give their coach Matt Williams a first Six Nations victory when Italy come to Edinburgh, but they again struggled to turn pressure into points.

Britain's economic future will be central to Labour's election campaign, Chancellor Gordon Brown has stated. He spoke after cabinet members had their last meeting at No 10 before the anticipated election announcement. Brown expressed that voters would recognize Labour's role in providing stability and growth, and would continue to do so. Meanwhile, the Tories outlined plans to address "yob culture," and the Lib Dems offered more details on their proposals to replace council tax. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury wrote to all three parties urging them not to exploit people's fears during the election. In an open letter, he called on them to avoid turning the election into a competition over who can most effectively frighten voters about terrorism, asylum, and crime.

Brizzel to run AAA's in Sheffield Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among eight of Ireland's European indoor hopefuls competing in this weekend's AAA's championships. U.S.-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish athletes selected so far for the Europeans who will not run in Sheffield. Brizzel will defend his 200m title in the British trials. In-form James McIlroy will hope to confirm his place in the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has been in tremendous form on the European circuit in recent weeks. He is one of the fastest 800m runners in the world this winter and already seems assured of a place in Madrid. Corkman Mark Carroll confirmed in midweek that he would join Cragg in the European championships. Carroll is ranked number three in the world 3000m ranking at the moment with Cragg occupying top spot.

Robinson seeks dual code success. England rugby union captain Jason Robinson has set his sights on dual code victory over Australia on Saturday. Robinson, a former rugby league international before switching codes in 2000, leads England against Australia at Twickenham at 1430 GMT. Then at 1815 GMT, Great Britain's rugby league team faces Australia in the Tri-Nations tournament final. "Beating the Aussies in both games would be a significant achievement, especially for league," said Robinson. England aims for their third autumn international triumph following victories over Canada and South Africa, and seeks revenge for June's 51-15 defeat by the Wallabies. Meanwhile, Great Britain could end 34 years of losses against Australia with a victory at Elland Road.

Warning over tsunami aid website: Net users are being advised to avoid a scam website that claims to collect funds on behalf of tsunami victims. The site appears plausible because it uses an outdated version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee webpage. However, the DEC has no connection with the fraudulent site and has reported it to the police. The site is just the latest in a long list of scams trying to exploit the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The link to the website is included in a spam email that is currently circulating. The message's subject line reads "Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal," and its content bears all the poor grammar and spelling that characterizes many other phishing attempts.

Iraq to invite phone license bids. Iraq is set to invite bids for two telephone licenses, aiming to significantly boost nationwide coverage over the next decade. Bids are invited from local, Arab, and international companies, Iraq's Ministry of Communications announced. The winner will collaborate with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC). The firms will install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax, and internet services. The ministry stated that it aims to increase Iraq's "very low telephone service penetration rate from about 4.5% today to about 25% within 10 years." It also seeks to develop a "highly visible and changeable telecommunications sector." Details of the bidding and tender process will be published on the ministry's website on February 9. It is also planning a roadshow for investors in Amman, Jordan.

More women are turning to net security. Older individuals and women are increasingly taking charge of protecting home computers against malicious net attacks, according to a two-year study. The number of women purchasing programs to protect PCs from virus, spam, and spyware attacks rose by 11.2% each year from 2002 to 2004. The study, conducted for net security firm Preventon, shows that security messages are reaching a wider range of users. It is thought that 40% of those buying home net security programs are retired. For the last three years, this percentage has increased by an average of 13.2%. Notably, more retired women (53%) were buying security software than retired men. The research reflects the changing demographics of web users and the growing awareness of the greater risks that high-speed broadband connections can pose to users.

Podcasts mark the rise of DIY radio. An Apple iPod or other digital music players can hold up to 10,000 songs, which is a lot of space to fill. But more and more iPod owners are filling that space with audio content created by a diverse assortment of producers. This is called "podcasting," and its strongest proponent is former MTV host and VJ (video jockey) Adam Curry. Podcasting takes its name from the Apple iPod, although you do not need an iPod to create or to listen to a podcast. A podcast is essentially an internet-based radio show that podcasters create, usually in the comfort of their own home. They need only a microphone, a PC, and some editing software. They then upload their shows to the internet, and others can download and listen to them, all for free.

Levy takes Whitbread Novel Prize. Orange Prize winner Andrea Levy has seen her book *Small Island* win the Whitbread Novel of the Year Award. She is now favored to win the overall prize after beating Booker winner Alan Hollinghurst's *The Line of Beauty*. Geraldine McCaughrean has picked up the Children's Fiction Award for the third time for *Not the End of the World*. All the category winners go through to compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which carries a £25,000 prize. A panel of judges including Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris will meet on 25 January to decide the overall winner, with the announcement made later that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has placed London-based Levy's novel as the 6/4 favorite to win.

Yukos seeks court action on sale. Yukos will return to a U.S. court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the little-known firm that has bought its main asset. Yukos has stated it will sue Baikal and others involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas for $20 billion in damages. Yukos' U.S. lawyers will attempt to have Baikal's assets frozen after the Russian government ignored a U.S. court order last week blocking the sale. Baikal's background and its motives for buying the unit remain unclear. Russian newspapers have claimed that Baikal—which purchased the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4 billion (261 billion roubles, £4.8 billion) on Sunday at a state-provoked auction—has strong links with Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-biggest oil producer.

Hearts 2-1 Livingston: Hearts wrapped up their Scottish Cup quarter-final tie against Livingston with two goals in the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller scored inside the opening 60 seconds, heading over Colin Meldrum and into the net from a Jamie McAllister free kick. McAllister himself scored the second when he met Saulius Mikoliunas' cross at the back post to put the game beyond the visitors. Craig Easton headed in a controversial goal after an hour, but Hearts held on. The opening goal came after Gus Bahoken had clumsily fouled Miller 35 yards from goal. McAllister floated the free kick into the Livi box, and Miller outjumped the static visiting defense to loop his header from 10 yards over Meldrum. With just 10 minutes on the clock, the home side doubled their lead. Mikoliunas sprinted down the right, crossed to the back post where McAllister raced in to head past Meldrum.

Sun Microsystems has launched a pay-as-you-go service, allowing customers in need of significant computing power to rent it by the hour. Sun Grid charges users $1 (53p) for an hour's worth of processing and storage power on systems maintained by Sun. Grid computing is the latest buzzword for a company that believes computing capacity is as crucial a commodity as hardware and software. Sun likened grid computing to the evolution of electricity. The system could mature similarly to utilities like electricity and water, said Sun's Chief Operating Officer Jonathan Schwartz. "Why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?" he asked during a webcast launching Sun's quarterly network computing event in California.

Jamieson issues warning to bigots: Scotland's justice minister has warned bigoted soccer fans that she plans to hit them "where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Cathy Jamieson said exclusion orders are among a series of measures being considered in the Scottish Executive campaign against sectarianism. She praised Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in tackling the problem. However, the minister stated that stopping sectarian abuse associated with Old Firm matches is a key objective. Ms. Jamieson was speaking ahead of the third-round Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead on Sunday. The sectarianism long associated with sections of the support from both clubs has become a significant target for the Executive. Last week, Ms. Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell met supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the issue.

UK debut for Kevin Spacey movie: Hollywood stars Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth attended the British premiere of the new film, Beyond the Sea, in London's Leicester Square on Thursday. Spacey, 45, wrote, directed, and starred in the film, inspired by the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. "This is my tribute to someone I think was a remarkable talent," said Spacey, who, as Darin, sings all 18 songs on the film's soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, plays Darin's wife—real-life Hollywood actress Sandra Dee. "I knew absolutely nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I'm a huge fan," said Bosworth, who attended the premiere with British boyfriend Orlando Bloom.

Leeds v Saracens (Fri) Headingley Friday, 25 February 2000 GMT The Tykes have brought in Newcastle prop Ed Kalman and Tom McGee from the Borders on loan while fly-half Craig McMullen has joined from Narbonne. Raphaël Ibañez is named at hooker for Saracens in one of four changes. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell are also selected in the pack while Kevin Sorrell comes in at outside centre. Friday's game at Headingley received approval on Friday after passing an early pitch inspection. Leeds: Balshaw; Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty; McMullen, Dickens; McGee, Rawlinson, Gerber; Murphy, Palmer (capt), Morgan, Parks, Popham. Replacements: Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMillan, Rock, Vickerman.

Home phones face an unclear future: the fixed-line phone in your home could soon be an endangered species. Research by handset maker Nokia shows that more and more people are using their mobile phones for every call they make or take. According to the study, over 45 million people in the UK, Germany, US, and South Korea now only use a mobile. It showed that people keep their fixed-line phone because call charges are lower, but most of those questioned said the future was definitely mobile. The Nokia-sponsored research showed that mobiles and fixed phones were used for different purposes. Home phones were used for longer calls, but conversations on mobiles tended to be shorter, between mobiles, and to friends. In the UK, 69% of those questioned said they turned to their fixed phone because it was still cheaper to use than a mobile.

MPs Tout Lords Replacement Plan A group of MPs has sought to increase pressure on Tony Blair over reform of the House of Lords by publishing a detailed blueprint for change. The cross-party group has released a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber in which 70% of members would be elected. MPs and peers have failed to agree on reform since 1999 when 600 hereditary peers lost their seats. The group says it can gain support for removing the last 92 hereditary peers. The government postponed plans to remove the remaining hereditary peers, as they believed they were unlikely to succeed after opposition in the Lords. Tony Blair has argued that there needs to be consensus on reforms. There have been suggestions there will be proposals for altering at least the powers of the Lords in Labour's manifesto.

Disappointed Scott in solid start: Allan Scott is confident of winning a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships after a solid debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the Jose M Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid. "It was definitely a learning curve and I certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete. The race was won by Felipe Vivancos, who equaled the Spanish record. Sweden's Robert Kronberg was second, with Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third. Scott was slightly disappointed with his run in the final. He won his heat in 7.64 seconds but ran 0.04 seconds slower in his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix Circuit final.

A U.S. woman sues over cartridges; a U.S. woman is suing Hewlett-Packard (HP), alleging its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a specific date. The unnamed woman from Georgia claims that a chip inside the cartridge indicates it needs refilling even when it does not. The lawsuit aims to represent anyone in the U.S. who has purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's largest printer firm, declined to comment on the lawsuit. HP ink cartridges use chip technology to detect when they are low on ink and advise the user to make a change. But the suit claims the chips also deactivate the cartridges at a predetermined date regardless of whether they are empty.

Virgin Radio offers 3G broadcast UK broadcaster Virgin Radio says it will become the first station in the world to offer radio via 3G mobiles. The radio station, in partnership with technology firm Sydus, will broadcast on selected 2G and high-speed 3G networks. Later this year, listeners will be able to download software from the Virgin website which enables the service. James Cridland, head of new media at Virgin Radio, said: "It places radio at the heart of the 3G revolution." Virgin Radio will be the first station made available, followed by two digital stations, Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove. Mr. Cridland said: "This application will enable anyone, anywhere to listen to Virgin Radio simply with the phone in their pocket.

Roxy Music on Isle of Wight bill: Roxy Music will appear at June's Isle of Wight Music Festival, along with Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. REM has already been confirmed as headliners for the three-day event, which takes place from 10-12 June. Original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson will take to the stage on the Saturday night of the festival. The band is also working in the studio on new material, their first since the 1982 album Avalon. Roxy Music was formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining the following year. Their first hit was 1972's Virginia Plain, with other hits including Street Life, Love Is the Drug, and the 1981 John Lennon cover, Jealous Guy.

Captains lining up for aid match: Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll is one of four Six Nations captains included in the Northern Hemisphere squad for the IRB rugby aid match on 5 March. France's Fabien Pelous, Gordon Bulloch of Scotland, and Italy's Marco Bortolami are also in the Northern party. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the Northern team against Rod Macqueen's Southern Hemisphere team in a tsunami fund-raising match at Twickenham. "I'm looking forward to working with such outstanding players," he said. It will be a chance for Woodward to assess some of his options before unveiling his British and Irish Lions touring party, who will visit New Zealand in the summer. "The game promises to be a great spectacle," he said.

The comedy "Sideways" has dominated this year's Independent Spirit Awards, winning all six categories for which it was nominated. It was named Best Film, while Alexander Payne won Best Director and Best Screenplay, along with writing partner Jim Taylor. It also won acting awards for stars Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen. "Sideways" is expected to do well at Sunday's Oscars, with five nominations. The awards, now in their 20th year, are given to films made outside the traditional studio system, and are traditionally held the day before the Oscars. Other winners included Catalina Sandino Moreno, who took Best Actress for her role as a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama "Maria Full of Grace." Moreno is also nominated for Best Actress at the Oscars. The Best First Screenplay award went to Joshua Marston for "Maria Full of Grace.

Prince crowned 'top music earner' Prince earned more than any other pop star in 2004, surpassing artists such as Madonna and Elton John in US magazine Rolling Stone's annual list. The singer banked $56.5m (£30.4m) from concerts, album, and publishing sales with his Musicology tour and album. He kept Madonna in second place, as she earned $54.9m (£29.5m) while embarking on her global Re-Invention tour. Veterans Simon and Garfunkel were in 10th place, their comeback tour helping them earn $24.9m (£13.4m) last year. "Prince returned to center stage after a decade in the commercial wilderness," the magazine reported. The singer's 2004 tour took $90.3m (£48.5m) in ticket sales, and he sold 1.9 million copies of his latest album Musicology.

Walmart fights back at accusers. Two major U.S. names have launched advertising campaigns to "set the record straight" about their products and corporate behavior. The world's largest retailer, Walmart, took out over 100 full-page ads in national newspapers. The group is aiming to fend off criticism over its pay deals, benefits package, and promotion strategy. Meanwhile, drug group Eli Lilly is planning a campaign against "false" claims about its product Prozac. Walmart initiated the battle with ads in newspapers like The Wall Street Journal, using an open letter from company president Lee Scott, stating it was time for the public to hear the "unfiltered truth." "There are many 'urban legends' circulating these days about Walmart, but facts are facts.

The Tories are outlining policing plans where local communities would be asked to go to the polls to elect their own area police commissioner, under plans unveiled by the Conservatives. Party leader Michael Howard said the new role would replace "inconspicuous" police authorities. He said the new office would not supersede the position of a chief constable. The Lib Dems said the plan could allow extreme groups to run policing, while Labour criticized "extravagant" Tory promises on policing. Responding to the plans, the chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, which represents rank-and-file officers, said it was essential that operational independence be maintained. Jan Berry said: "It is a service, not a political football to be kicked around every time an election approaches." "These plans could result in those with extreme political views dictating what actually happens on the ground," she warned.

At a glance: Tory health checks—The UK’s opposition Conservatives have announced plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's a guide to the plan: People coming to live and work in Britain from outside the EU, intending to stay for six months or more and hailing from countries with high TB rates, would need a chest X-ray and further tests if necessary. All individuals from outside the European Union who wish to stay a year or more must undergo a full medical examination for tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive test for TB would automatically result in visa applications being denied. All other conditions would be considered on a case-by-case basis.

Paris promise raises Welsh hopes: Has there been a better Six Nations match than Saturday's epic in Paris? And can the Welsh revival continue all the way to a first Grand Slam since 1978? These are the two questions occupying not just Wales supporters but rugby fans as a whole after a scintillating display in Paris. Welsh legend Mervyn Davies, a member of two of three Grand Slam-winning sides of the 1970s, hailed it as "one of the great performances of the past three decades." Martyn Williams, Wales' two-try scorer on the day, called it "one of the most surreal games I have ever played in." A crestfallen France coach, Bernard Laporte, simply observed: "There was a French half and there was a Welsh half.

Doves soar to UK album summit as Manchester rock band Doves have landed at number one on the UK album chart with their new release, Some Cities. The trio replace the flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters at the top. The album follows the single Black and White Town, which reached number six. R&B star Nelly now has the number one single with Over and Over, which sees him collaborate with Tim McGraw. Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs all have new singles in the top ten, as do Futureheads and Usher. The latest Elvis Presley re-release, (Marie's the Name) His Latest Flame, entered the chart at number three, one place ahead of Girls Aloud's Wake Me Up. Hip-hop artist Akon's Locked Up is at number five, while the promising Leeds band Kaiser Chiefs have their second chart hit at number six with Oh My God.

Davies favors Gloucester Future Wales hooker Mefin Davies is likely to stay with English side Gloucester despite reported interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. BBC Wales understands the Ospreys are interested in the 32-year-old, but he would prefer to stay where he is. Davies, one of the stars of Saturday's RBS Six Nations win over England, is only on a one-year contract at Kingsholm. However, the hooker has proved his worth to the Zurich Premiership side and is likely to get a new deal next season. The summer demise of the Celtic Warriors region left Davies in the cold and forced him to take a semi-professional contract with Neath RFC. Although he got match time with the Ospreys at the request of the Wales management, he admitted before his move to Gloucester that he was angry with the way he was treated.

Cabinet upset at Brown cash raid; ministers are unhappy about plans to use Whitehall funds to keep council tax bills down, local government minister Nick Raynsford has acknowledged. Gordon Brown reallocated £512m from central to local government budgets in his pre-budget report on Thursday. Mr. Raynsford said he had held some "pretty frank discussions" with fellow ministers over the plans. But he said local governments had to deliver good services without significant council tax increases. The central government funds are part of a £1bn package to help local authorities in England keep next year's council tax rises below 5%, in what is likely to be a general election year. Mr. Raynsford said nearly all central government departments have an interest in well-run local authorities.

Israeli club looks to Africa; four African players, including Zimbabwe goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, are all set to play for Israeli club Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin in the UEFA Cup. Bnei Sakhnin is the first Arab side ever to play in European competition and will face English Premiership side Newcastle United in the first round. Warriors' goalkeeper Murambadoro, who made his mark at the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, helped Bnei Sakhnin overcome Albania's Partizani Tirana 6-1 in the previous round. Murambadoro moved to Israel recently after a brief stint with South African club Hellenic. The club won the Israeli Cup final last season and is based in Sakhnin, near Haifa. The club embraces a strong ethic and is a high-profile promoter of peace and cooperation within Israel.

A new drink limit could save more lives than previously anticipated by reducing drink-drive limits by a third, a report reveals. University College London research claims cutting the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would save 65 lives a year. The findings are being published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety as MPs prepare to vote on the government's road safety bill. The bill includes changes to speeding fines but not to the drink-drive limit. The research, conducted by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, suggests that reducing the limit would also result in 230 fewer serious injuries on the UK’s roads compared with 2003. He estimates that this would save the country £119m annually. A previous estimate, contained in a 1998 Department of Transport document, suggested such a move could save 50 lives a year.

This paper presents a millimeter-scale CMOS 64$\times$64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1$\times$1 $\mu m^2$ diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design provides a large detection area of 512$\times$512 $\mu m^2$. Instead of sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures the pulse width, i.e., the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline. This eliminates the need for power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC is fabricated in TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process and consumes an average static power of 0.535 mW under a 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The functionality of the entire system is successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam setting.

Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been shown to reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that AVs would readily allow themselves to be controlled externally by a central agency is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme aiming to incentivize AVs to seek centrally controlled system optimal (SO) routing by saving on tolls, while user equilibrium (UE) seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HVs) are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, where dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, and the lower level is a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model considering a mixed fleet of AVs and HVs.

Optomechanics and electromechanics have made it possible to prepare macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, in quadrature squeezed states, and in entangled states of motion. In addition to coaxing ever larger and more tangible objects into a regime of quantum behavior, this new capability has fostered ideas of using mechanical oscillators in the processing and communication of quantum information and as precision force sensors operating beyond the standard quantum limit. However, the effectively linear interaction between motion and light or electricity precludes access to the broader class of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Indeed, early optomechanical proposals noted the potential to escape this restriction by creating strong quadratic coupling of motion to light. Although experimental demonstrations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems exist, they have not yet accessed nonclassical states of motion.

Online reviews provide product evaluations for customers to make informed decisions. Unfortunately, these evaluations can be manipulated through fake reviews ("spams") by professional spammers, who have learned increasingly insidious and powerful strategies to adapt to deployed detectors. Spamming strategies are challenging to capture, as they can change rapidly over time, vary among spammers and target products, and, more critically, remain unknown in most cases. Furthermore, most existing detectors focus on detection accuracy, which is not aligned with the goal of maintaining the trustworthiness of product evaluations. To address these challenges, we formulate a minimax game where the spammers and spam detectors compete based on practical goals that are not solely focused on detection accuracy. Nash equilibria of the game lead to stable detectors that are agnostic to any mixed detection strategies.

We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high fidelity (uh-fidelity) population transfer in a 3-level quantum system in lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we use the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method to derive a family of solutions leading to an exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the L-R invariant.
